urn:contentItem:5XDW-JS91-JBDN-3000-00000-00Bulls And Bears Of The Week: Apple, Facebook, Starbucks, Wayfair And More2019-11-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisBulls And Bears Of The Week: Apple, Facebook, Starbucks, Wayfair And MoreNelson Hem

Benzinga has examined the prospects for many investor favorite stocks over the past week.

Bullish calls included top big tech stocks and a favorite coffee purveyor.

Bearish calls also included tech and popular consumer-facing stocks.

The World Series and Halloween have come and gone, and November and the rush to year's end is here. The major U.S. indexes eked out additional marginal gains in another volatile week, which also saw another   federal funds rate cut, news of   a big auto merger and a   robust employment report for October.

As usual, Benzinga continues to examine the prospects for many of the stocks most popular with investors. Here are just a few of this past week's most bullish and bearish posts that may be worth another look.

Bulls

Dave Royse's "Facebook's Strong Quarter, Outlook Have Sell-Side Hitting Like On The Stock" shares why regulatory issues are unlikely to permanently hurt the share value of Facebook, Inc. (NASDAQ: FB).

Alphabet Inc (NASDAQ: GOOGL) is still firing on all cylinders, according to analysts in Wayne Duggan's "Hey Google! Sell-Side Sentiment Solid After Alphabet's Q3 Earnings Disappoint."

"Bank Of America Cites 3 Reasons For Recommending Intel" by Priya Nigam shows why execution is improving at Intel Corporation (NASDAQ: INTC). Find out what to expect from the semiconductor leader in 2020.

In "Analysts Drink Up Starbucks' Solid Quarter," Elizabeth Balboa looks at why analysts remain optimistic about the prospects for Starbucks Corporation (NASDAQ: SBUX) in the wake of it most recent earnings report.

For additional bullish calls, also have a look at In Defense Of Pinterest? These Analysts Stay Positive After Earnings Drop and   Analysts Upbeat On AMD's Product Roadmap, Execution.

Bears

Craig Adeyanju's "Apple's Recovery In China Threatened by Competitors' 5G" offers a look at how the impending rollout of the 5G network in China could disrupt the Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL) comeback in the country.

Smart money is expecting AT&T Inc. (NYSE: T) to underperform following its highly anticipated HBO Max streaming launch, according to "Large AT&T Option Trades Mostly Bearish Following Earnings Beat" by Wayne Duggan.

In Priya Nigam's "KeyBanc On Wayfair: Powerful Consumer Offering, But Profitability Elusive," find out why Wayfair Inc (NYSE: W) blamed tariffs for its revenue growth slowdown. But was there more to the story?

"Leading The Way? Analysts Not Yet Ready To Buy Mattel Despite Earnings Beat, Stock Surge" by Elizabeth Balboa examines why some are cautious despite the apparent recovery at Mattel Inc (NYSE: MAT).

Be sure to check out AMAG Pharmaceuticals Falls 25% After FDA Recommends Removing Makena From The Market and   Analysts Stay Bearish On Western Union Despite New 52-Week Highs for additional bearish calls.

Keep up with all the latest breaking news and trading ideas by following Benzinga on Twitter.

urn:contentItem:5WR8-39P1-JBDN-30JC-00000-00Bulls And Bears Of The Week: Boeing, GM, Pfizer, Starbucks And More2019-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisBulls And Bears Of The Week: Boeing, GM, Pfizer, Starbucks And MoreNelson Hem

Benzinga has examined the prospects for many investor favorite stocks over the past week.

Bullish calls included an underappreciated automaker and a leading pharmaceutical.

Bearish calls included FAANG stocks and an aerospace giant.

Healthy earnings reports from sector leaders like Apple,   General Electric and   Exxon, as well the anticipated   federal funds rate cut, were not enough to buoy the markets last week as the   trade war with China escalated, another   big data breach was revealed and the latest   employment numbers were unremarkable. The big U.S. indexes all saw declines, led by the Nasdaq at almost 4%.

As usual, Benzinga continues to examine the prospects for many of the stocks most popular with investors. Here are just a few of this past week's most bullish and bearish posts that may be worth another look.

Bulls

After the success of the recent Fortnite World Cup Finals in New York, plays in the sector include Amazon.com, Inc. (NASDAQ: AMZN), according to Brett Hershman's "Analyst Likes Amazon, Logitech, Turtle Beach After Fortnite World Cup."

Dave Royse's "Citi: GM Truck Story Strong And Underappreciated" takes a look why quarterly results from General Motors Company (NYSE: GM) are sustainable for reasons that are unique but not well understood.

"Merck's Keytruda Gets A Double Dose Of Positive News" by Shanthi Rexaline discusses how the wonder cancer immunotherapy from Merck & Co., Inc. (NYSE: MRK) has managed to notch sever clinical and regulatory milestones this year.

In "Wedbush Sees Upside In Zynga Beyond Video Game Company's Lifted Guidance," Priya Nigam shows why guidance from Zynga Inc (NASDAQ: ZNGA) could prove conservative in light of new game launches.

For additional bullish calls, also have a look at Analysts More Bullish On McDonald's After 'Thesis-Affirming Quarter' and   Wells Fargo Initiates Bullish Coverage On Dell.

Bears

Wayne Duggan's "Fitch: Boeing's Credit Rating Could Be Cut" indicates that the 737 Max nightmare may not be over for Boeing Co (NYSE: BA) and its investors. This ratings agency already has a "negative" outlook the aerospace giant.

Facebook, Inc. (NASDAQ: FB) and other big tech face new scrutiny from regulatory and government bodies. So says "Big Tech Faces Big Scrutiny: FTC Looking Into Facebook, Federal Reserve Pays Amazon A Visit" by Jayson Derrick.

"Morgan Stanley Downgrades Pfizer In Wake Of Upjohn-Mylan Merger" by Dave Royse suggests that the earnings for Pfizer Inc (NYSE: PFE) could be lower than anticipated after the upcoming spin-off.

In Brett Hershman's "JPMorgan Says Starbucks Valuation Has Become 'Beyond A Stretch'," see why 2020 may see a significant moderation in overall comps at Starbucks Corporation (NASDAQ: SBUX).

Be sure to check out Cannabis Stocks Are The Latest Target Of Short Sellers and   This Analyst Doesn't Want To Own Apple for additional bearish calls.

Keep up with all the latest breaking news and trading ideas by following Benzinga on Twitter.

value.Title: 'Bullying' Apple fights couple over pear logo
value.Overview: When Natalie Monson started her food blog 11 years ago, she didn't expect to end up embroiled in a fight with the world's most valuable company. urn:contentItem:60K0-M4D1-JCSC-J17S-00000-00'Bullying' Apple fights couple over pear logo2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisNEWS'Bullying' Apple fights couple over pear logo

When Natalie Monson started her food blog 11 years ago, she didn't expect to end up embroiled in a fight with the world's most valuable company. But the US small business owner is now battling Apple for the right to use a pear in the logo on her recipe app... When Natalie Monson started her food blog...

When Natalie Monson started her food blog 11 years ago, she didn't expect to end up embroiled in a fight with the world's most valuable company. But the US small business owner is now battling Apple for the right to use a pear in the logo on her recipe app...

When Natalie Monson started her food blog 11 years ago, she didn't expect to end up embroiled in a fight with the world's most valuable company. But the US small business owner is now battling Apple for the right to use a pear in the logo on her recipe app. In a patent filing, Apple said the image was too similar to its own logo and would hurt its brand. Ms Monson says the tech giant is simply "bullying" and she feels a "moral obligation" to fight back. More than 43,000 people have already signed the petition she and her husband Russ, owners of the Super Healthy Kids website, created last week to try to pressure the company to back down. McDonald's loses second 'Mc' trademark case Lindt defeats Haribo over gold bear "This is a real world example of a small business being destroyed by a giant monopoly because they don't have accountability," Mr Monson told the BBC. "That was so frustrating to us that we thought we had to do something. We can't just be the next victim on the list." Apple did not respond to a request for comment. 'Similar commercial impression' In its filing with the US patent office, the firm says the Monsons' pear logo "consists of a minimalistic fruit design with a right-angled leaf, which readily calls to mind Apple's famous Apple Logo and creates a similar commercial impression, as shown in the following side-by-side comparison". It asks regulators to reject the Monsons' trademark application, which the couple first filed in 2017 on behalf of their recipe and meal planning app, Prepear. Ms Monson said the comparison took them by surprise. The shape of the pear and leaf, which they worked on with a designer, was supposed to allude to the letter "P" in the app's name, she said. "We had no intention or any awareness that it was copying any logo at all," she said. "We thought it was very unique and designed it to be so." "First we were very surprised and then I would say our second reaction was definitely scared," she added. "Like, 'ok where do we go from here? What does this mean?'" 'You wonder if it's a joke' When the couple started planning Prepear five years ago, they envisioned the app as a platform where food bloggers could upload recipes, which subscribers could access to plan meals shopping lists. They now have about 21,000 monthly active users, including 3,000 customers who pay the annual $59 fee, according to Mr Monson, an accountant by training. The app, along with the Super Health Kids site, supports five staff, including the couple. Mr Monson said he initially thought it was a misunderstanding and the two sides would be able to resolve the dispute amicably. The logo has been approved in other countries, including the UK, without dispute and American patent officials hadn't found a problem, he noted. As a final step before approval, the patent office published their application in late 2019 drawing Apple's objection. "It just seems so ridiculous on its face," he said. "You wonder if it's a joke." Last week, as it became clear that it was not, the couple spoke out on social media, drawing attention to other instances of Apple's trademark objections and noting that concerns about legal costs had prompted them to let go one of their employees. Skip Instagram post by superhealthykids View this post on Instagram Dear Instagram Friends- I NEED YOUR HELP! I know there are a lot of heavy things going on in the world right now, and this is nothing in comparison, but I need your help in a situation that is affecting me, my family, and my coworkers. Please help! Many of you know that I started a business called Prepear almost 5 years ago. It is an app that you can store all your recipes in one place, plan your meals, make grocery lists, and get your groceries delivered all in one place. Recently @apple yes, The trillion dollar Apple, has decided to oppose and go after our small business’ trademark saying our pear logo is too close to their apple logo and supposedly hurts their brand? This is a big blow to us at Prepear. To fight this it will cost tens of thousands of dollars. The CRAZY thing is that Apple has done this to dozens of other other small business fruit logo companies, and many have chosen to abandon their logo, or close doors. While the rest of the world is going out of their way to help small businesses during this pandemic, Apple has chosen to go after our small business. I’m not trying to get anyone to stop using or buying Apple products. I feel a moral obligation to take a stand against Apple's aggressive legal action against small businesses and fight for the right to keep our logo. We are defending ourselves against Apple not only to keep our logo, but to send a message to big tech companies that bullying small businesses has consequences. HOW YOU CAN HELP: 1 Sign the petition (link in my bio or in my stories) 2 Share that same link on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. http://chng.it/QPd2mRYW #savethepearfromapple A post shared by Healthy Kids Recipes•Routines (@superhealthykids) on Aug 7, 2020 at 12:56pm PDT End of Instagram post by superhealthykids Their story was picked up by iPhone in Canada and has since spread, drawing fresh attention to debates about whether tech giants are abusing their powers. "We're honestly overwhelmed by how supportive people have been," Mr Monson said. "It's incredible to see how many people share the same frustration that made us decide to take this public." Some of the people reaching out have offered legal and design help, so Mr Monson said he has no plans to back down in the fight anytime soon. "We're going to take it all the way," he said.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V03-1PH1-JD3N-5070-00000-00Bullying rules for big tech2018-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22Bullying rules for big techEXCLUSIVE ANNIKA SMETHURST NATIONAL POLITICAL EDITOR

SOCIAL media giants such as Facebook, Google and Twitter are under mounting pressure to stamp out harmful behaviour online as part of a government crackdown.

The tougher rules are part of a $17 million package in Monday's Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook (MYEFO) aimed at keeping kids safe online.

The Morrison government will create an online safety charter for big tech firms. The guidelines won't be legally binding but are -expected to include accountability measures to encourage firms to take stronger action against cyber-bullying and violent content.

If they fail to reform, the government could follow up with EU-style laws making them liable for harm and allow victims to take legal action.

Communications Minister Mitch Fifield said the guidelines would outline expectations for the industry to ensure the safety of children online.

"Businesses who interact with children in the real world have to meet high standards of safety and digital businesses should be treated no differently," Mr Fifield said.

"Nothing can be more important than protecting our children and â€¦ this means defending them from dangers from the online -environment." The crackdown comes after a Senate inquiry into -cyber-bullying laws recommended the government "maintain regulatory pressure" on social media companies and set up duty of care laws targeting Facebook and Instagram.

"(The Committee) wishes to make it clear that it is up to social media platforms to make their platforms safe environments, reduce the incidences of cyber-bullying and promptly take down all offending material," the report said.

The inquiry heard that Kids Helpline received 3000 calls about cyber-safety in 2017, including almost 1000 children worried about cyber-bullying.The government will consult with the tech companies and parents over coming months to develop the online safety charter, which will be unveiled before the election.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TYW-YS61-F0JP-W0VH-00000-00Bully rules for big tech2018-12-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Bully rules for big techANNIKA SMETHURST

SOCIAL media giants such as Facebook, Google and Twitter have been put on notice by the Federal Government to remove harmful content which appears online.

The Morrison Government will outline its expectations for social media companies in a new charter in an effort to stop cyber bullies and keep children safe online.

The new guidelines won't be legally binding but will demand tech companies remove harmful and illegal content.

They will also include accountability measures, with an explicit focus on keeping children safe.

Communications Minister Mitch Fifield said businesses that interacted with children in the real world had to meet high standards of safety and "digital businesses should be treated no differently".

The Government will consult the tech companies and parents over the coming months to develop the online safety charter, which will be unveiled before the next election.

The crackdown comes after a 2018 Senate inquiry into cyber-bullying laws recommended the Government "maintain regulatory pressure" on social media companies and set up duty-of-care laws targeting Facebook and Instagram.

Such laws would mean social media companies could be liable if users were bullied or harmed.

The inquiry heard that Kids Helpline received 3000 calls about cyber safety in 2017 and that there was a 133 per cent spike in cyber-bullying reports in the first two weeks of February, when children returned to school.

Mother of three Olivia Metcalf, who is a university researcher in the excessive use of technology, welcomed the Government's stronger stance.

Dr Metcalf said she was worried her three boys would be exposed to violent or sexual content available online.

"Online safety is a really big concern. When I talk to parents, we are all really worried about it," she said.

The Morrison Government's stance is part of a $17 million package to be revealed in tomorrow's Mid Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook aimed at keeping children safe online.More than $3 million will be spent over the next four years researching the effects of cyber-bullying on vulnerable internet users, including indigenous communities.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MSN-N1G1-DXH2-6002-00000-00Bundle Up!; Chaos On Campus; Confirmation Roadblocks; Awaiting Pres. Trump Speech at National Prayer Breakfast2017-02-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTPeter Kiernan, Morgan Ortagus, Ted Eliopoulos, Tim Ryan, Peter Kiernan, Jack BrewerNEWSDomestic020203cb.231Bundle Up!; Chaos On Campus; Confirmation Roadblocks; Awaiting Pres. Trump Speech at National Prayer BreakfastMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Lauren Simonetti

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK MORNINGS WITH MARIA HOST: -- this morning, keep your winter coats at the forefront of your closet. More winter is on the way. We heard from Punxsutawney Phil earlier and he did see his shadow six more weeks of winter. All that coming up this morning. And joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network Dagen McDowell, former Goldman Sachs partner and New York Times best-selling author Peter Kiernan and Maverick PAC National Co-Chair Morgan Ortagus. Good to see you. Were you laughing at me?

(CROSSTALK)

PETER KIERNAN, NEW YORK TIMES BEST-SELLING AUTHOR: Glad to be with you.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You know, you had your coat on at the break (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: It's a little chilly, and I'm still getting over that flu I had, like, two weeks ago.

BARTIROMO: That is right.

KIERNAN: Youth comes back fast. Youth comes back fast, you've bounced right back.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Youth? Yes. That's -- I don't even -- I'm so beyond that. I don't even know what that word means anymore.

BARTIROMO: Come on. We got -- we got a big show ahead. Look, we've seen the markets trade to the flat this year on the heels of the big rally after election night. We're going to talk with the chief investment officer CalPERS coming up, how he's allocating hundreds of billions of dollars right now, and you wonder if in fact he's expecting the strength in the market to continue. What we need to hear from President Trump and his administration.

So, Ted Eliopoulos will weigh in. He's the CIO of CalPERS. Plus, OhioCongressman Tim Ryan is with us this morning. Of course, he tried to go up against Nancy Pelosi and lost that bid. We'll talk with Tim Ryan about the Democratically Party. And the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighing in as always. Along with former NFL Star Jack Brewer. You don't want to miss a moment of it. We got a big hour ahead so stay with us this morning.

And we kick it off with those violent protests last night erupting at the University of California, Berkeley Campus, over a speech from conservative editor, Milo Yiannopoulos. Rioters started fires, they broke windows -- look at this, they confronted police, ultimately causing the event to be canceled. Joining us right now is the University of Virginia Center for Politics Director Larry Sabato. Larry, thanks very much for joining us. And what do you have to say about this violence?

LARRY SABATO, UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA CENTER FOR POLITICS DIRECTOR: Well, as Peter Kiernan knows, I'm from the University of Virginia. I've been associated with university for 47 years, it is Thomas Jefferson's University. We believe in free speech, I've had literally a hundreds of speakers that I've brought in to the university from right to left and everything in between, I've never had a single problem. So obviously, what happened at Berkeley was wrong.

You've got lots of choices, you can boycott an event you don't like, you can peacefully protester it, you can go and ask questions during the Q and A period, you hold a counter event, what you should not do is to shut down the actual event and deny someone the right to speak, if they've been invited by a group and it's follow the rules of that university. So, this is not a good thing, but let's not overgeneralize, this is one university, I'm sure it's happened elsewhere but there are plenty of universities, like the University of Virginia not nearly as good but like they're like the University of Virginia and that they welcome speakers.

BARTIROMO: Well, we don't -- we don't want to generalize about universities across the board but there is a thread that goes through universities across the board frankly, I mean, not cutting off free speech but you said that so, I -- what I really wanted to say to you was who's accountable, who do you guys think is accountable? Should leadership from University of Berkeley U.C. have come and put an end to it? What could have been done to stop this?

MCDOWELL: Right. Right. That it ultimately falls into the hands of the leadership of the university, and quite frankly, it leads to anecdotally there is this move -- this thread among universities particularly with a lot of professors that there is -- there's no room in the classroom for a differing opinion.

SABATO: Well, you know, I can't speak for every university or every professor or every classroom. I sure know my students don't fear me at all and they constantly object to this, that, and the other, and raise contrary opinions and I encourage it and that's what you should do in a classroom. So, when you say there's a --

BARTIROMO: And you said Peter Kiernan knows that.

KIERNAN: Yes. Well --

SABATO: He knows that. He knows that.

KIERNAN: Larry has taught all four of my children and in the process he's taught me a heck of a lot too. And I think, you know, what we're talking about here though is I think a shared community obligation. It can't just be that something that the president does alone or the faculty does alone or the students. There are many stakeholders here and I think what UVA does uniquely well and could be a -- I think a magnet for other people to watch is bring all these forces together in a way useful that it's useful. And I think what you're seeing in going on in Berkeley and U.C. Davis is not useful in any way and the person ultimately harmed frankly is the student.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's true.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PAC NATIONAL CO-CHAIR: Well, why not hold the student -- if you peacefully protest, that's fine. You have every right to peacefully previous as much as you do to have free speech. But how about holding the students who are violent and accountable in some many sort of punishment so that other students know you can peacefully protest that you can't -- you can't burn building and break windows, I mean, that's just silly. And you're responsible.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KIERNAN: No. It's true. Absolutely, you have to hold --

BARTIROMO: Yes. We all live free on this but unfortunately this bias continues throughout the university.

MCDOWELL: I had it at Wake Forest for a shoot, I had it down in Wake Forest in the late 80s where it was like my speech was only was free if it agreed with some of my professors and I was targeted because I was in a sorority and some of my professors didn't like that. And so, I think that this has gotten away from itself because there's a lack of leadership, I'm not talking about the University of Virginia but it's certainly a lack of leadership or it's just a control of the liberal left.

KIERNAN: Professor Sabato, I want to if I could ask you one question and that is you've seen -- you've seen them come and go, you've seen contentious elections, you've seen contentious campaigns but what is the -- what is the way for us to evaluate and think about Trump's start, he's done some great things, he's had speed bumps. Where do you see him in continuum of things and what should we be taking from this is just starting out and rough spots and what should be longer term concerns if there are any?

SABATO: Well, he's been in office for 14 days. It is a four-year term. I told people, you know, suspend judgment, you give anybody a reasonable trial period. Whenever we start a new job, often we have a rough period, so, you know, his supporters are pleased, they're focusing on the things they like, and his opponents, their disbeliefs, they're focusing on things they don't like. Let's see how this turns out as we move into, you know, a six-month period or the first 100 days ends which ends at the end of April. That seems like a much fair trial period.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let me switch gears and ask you about the president's cabinet, I mean, obviously another member was added yesterday, former ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson, Larry was confirmed and sworn in as secretary of state but there are other nominees that are facing real roadblocks. Two republican senators say they will vote against Trump's pick for education secretary, that's Betsy DeVos, If these senators follow through, republicans would only need one more no vote to block DeVos' appointment, what do you think here? That the White House administration shared their confidence that Betsy DeVos would be confirmed and listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEAN SPICER, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: I have one hundred percent confidence she will be next secretary of education. She is unbelievably qualified educator, an advocate for students, teachers, parents. It will be, you know, I think that the games that are being played with Betsy DeVos are sad.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: How do you see it, Larry? Do you think she will get confirmed?

SABATO: Well, obviously it's a -- it's a close call. Let's remember, historically a president losses on one cabinet member, either the person is forced to withdraw or doesn't pass the senate. Something happens usually to at least one some have two or three, I think DeVos might be the only one, I don't know whether she will lose another republican or not or whether she will gain one democratic vote, you know, there's always Senator Joe Manchin from West Virginia, I haven't heard him speak yet on how he's going to vote, maybe he issued a statement and I missed it.

But, you know, the broader picture is -- I think represented by someone like Rex Tillerson. I've had the opportunity to meet Mr. Tillerson talk with him in his prior role over the years on a number of occasions. I think he will make a very good secretary, I think people will be surprised that how well-trained he has become, thanks to being CEO of ExxonMobil which is big and has its own foreign policy.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Larry.

MCDOWELL: Larry, in terms of how the democrats handle four years of the Trump administration because there is so much outrage on social media about the Hillary Clinton loss, about Donald Trump, and they're really pushing the leadership whether it's Nancy Pelosi or Chuck Schumer to fight the Trump administration at every single step. Is this what we're going to get for four years and will it get worse?

SABATO: I don't think you will and I certainly don't think it's wise to do that simply because you can't fight everything, I mean, that's -- it's absurd to even try to do that, you have to focus your attention on items or individuals that really concern you. And actually the Supreme Court nominee is going to be a good test, do you -- do you really spend all of your limited ammunition on somebody who's almost certain to be confirmed?

And it's a pretty impressive person when you listen to him, you read his credentials, whether you agree with him or not, I mean, that's not -- that's beside the point. Or do you wait for that critical change that's coming when Ginsburg or Kennedy or Briar steps aside, that's when the court will change. That's when to use your ammunition. Don't lose the filibuster on Gorsuch.

So there are important distinctions here and it's up to the leadership, you mentioned, leadership in universities, it's up to party leadership to make that case to the rank and file. If they're angry, they're angry but they also have to -- have to use sense.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But I mean, what about all the other be pushback from these -- from, you know, on these nominees? I mean, do you think this is obstruction by the democrats or is this just politics as usual?

SABATO: Well, it's -- this is a continuum. If you look back over, you know, 30 years, you'll see that it's gotten worse and worse and worse just as polarization has gotten worse. So I would say with each do administration we seem to go a step or two or three further along this line of division which is not healthy for the country.

BARTIROMO: No. It isn't.

SABATO: I don't have much optimism that it's going to change any time soon.

BARTIROMO: All right, Larry. We'll leave it there. Good to see you. Thanks so much. Larry Sabato.

SABATO: Thanks a lot. Take care.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a short break. When we come back we are awaiting remarks from President Trump at the National Prayer Breakfast, you see that on the bottom of your screen here. And then coming up. First Lady Melania Trump getting ready for a big change as she's gearing up for move to the White House, that's next. And then investors hoping for a belated Christmas gift on Amazon's 4th quarter earnings. What to expect from the Ecommerce retailer straight ahead.

BARTIROMO: Market this morning expected to open lower, stocks soared after the presidential election of course, but the Trump rally has been slowing down, this year, leading investors to look into Trump policy before they make their next move. Joining me right now is CalPERS Chief Investment Officer Ted Eliopoulos joining us right now. And Ted, it's great to have you on the show today..

TED ELIOPOULOS, CALPERS CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER: Maria, thank you --

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

ELIOPOULOS: Thank you for having me. It's so nice to be here.

BARTIROMO: You know, it's important to check in with you because you are overseeing such a massive amount of capital, $306 billion, is that right? The AUM at CalPERS right now?

ELIOPOULOS: That's exactly right.

BARTIROMO: How are you allocating that and has it changed with the new administration coming in?

ELIOPOULOS: Well, we're allocating it according to our long-term strategic asset allocation of course and we're heavily waited to equities in our strategic allocation. And really going into this U.S. election, we position the portfolio to -- take into account both the hopes for equity allocations in the future but also the risks of this election. Post- election is really the same story. There is much hope and optimism for growth in the U.S. in positioning of portfolios to take advantage of that growth. CalPERS benefited immensely from the run-up in equity markets over the last month and a half for sure. Now the question really is as you know, what happens in the future?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, I think this market was really rallying on the idea that we would see corporate tax reform, obviously a 15 percent corporate tax rate or a 20 percent corporate tax rate, would do a lot for earnings, yes?

ELIOPOULOS: Yes, it would. As well as regulatory reform.

BARTIROMO: Right.

ELIOPOULOS: Both would be very productive for growth in the U.S. and translate to better earnings, better equity returns for the future. But there are also some risks to take into account. One is what impact on inflation, we have been on a -- in a very low inflation -- inflationary environment and what impact could be on inflation is something to keep an eye on.

BARTIROMO: How do you prepare yourself as an asset manager for that? I mean when you look at inflation perhaps on the horizon, does that change your assessment of what to do with bonds versus stocks?

ELIOPOULOS: Well, it's very difficult spot for investors right now because you have to prepare for some divergent outcomes is -- are we having inflationary environment going forward or continue to have a deflationary environment? There is no one portfolio that's going to be maximized in each of those environment. So, for CalPERS, we have such a dominate equity position in our portfolio, almost 48 percent of the portfolio today. We have bought some inflation protective securities and repositioned the portfolio as well as commodities in the run-up to the election.

BARTIROMO: In terms of 48 percent in equities, is that through index funds, ETFs or specific names?

ELIOPOULOS: We're direct in the -- in that global index of stocks, so we are predominantly an index investor with enhancements that we do mostly internally with our internal global equity.

BARTIROMO: What are the enhancements? Tell us about that because today, you can buy an index with whatever combination you want, right?

ELIOPOULOS: That's right. So, we have several factors we look at, it could be momentum, value, quality, low volatility, maximum diversification, there are risk factors that allow us to tilt the portfolio slightly in directions that we see benefit.

BARTIROMO: When you look at overall areas that you have to allocate capital, we talked in the past about hedge funds and you've been vocal about -- look, the fees are something to watch, and it's not as, you know, a profitable thing anymore as well as private equity. You're developing plans to shift somewhat, $30 billion in terms of private equity away from - - what are you doing in terms of shifting?

ELIOPOULOS: Sure, yes

BARTIROMO: You're going to move in-house as pensions cut fees.

ELIOPOULOS: Yes. We're trying to bring as much in-house as we can, we have over 70 percent of our portfolio we managed internally. Most of that is in a public asset classes. We have added a new allocation to actually opportunistic credit, to new credit strategy, structured credit, private, we think that's an opportunity for the future. And that bringing -- we have that talent in-house, we have active fixed income managers within our staff that are able to execute those strategies with confidence.

In the private market much is a much tougher assessment whether you can bring in-house, those strategies, and we're not sure right now on the private equity side that we could effectuate a strategy to compete with the external managers that are our partners that have done extraordinarily well for us overtime. The fees are high but the returns and the performance net of all those fees have been quite robust, and persistent for over 20 years for now -- for us now. So, it is a very important calculus to try and adjust the external internal model internally.

BARTIROMO: Do you have any concern that we're not going to see the tax cuts and the rollback of regulations instituted this year and would that dictate a change in the way you invest in all those equities?

ELIOPOULOS: Well, we'll stay heavily invested in equities for the long term, we are a long-term investor, we'll be watching quite closely over the next six months to see how difficult and how swift these policy changes may come.

BARTIROMO: Because people are wondering if in fact, you know, there's money for this. I mean, yes, they want it revenue neutral and one of the president's underlying Mick Mulvaney says, look, we got to take a chopping block to the entitlements as the guy running who's running the largest pension fund, CalPERS out there in the country, what's your take on cutting entitlements?.

ELIOPOULOS: Well, you know, these are -- these are promises that have been made to -- ordinary pensioners, that's our -- that's our view. For CalPERS, our duty is to pensioners and we have hardworking policemen, firemen firewomen --

BARTIROMO: Going to keep those promises.

ELIOPOULOS: You have to keep those promises, so the key to make sure you price them and you save for them in order to keep those promises for the long term.

BARTIROMO: Ted, it's great to have you on the show today.

ELIOPOULOS: Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. Ted Eliopoulos is the chief investment officer of CalPERS. We have breaking news right now, the hostage situation at a Delaware Prison. The prison is now secure, one hostage has been found dead, another has been hospitalized. This breaking news just happening, we are going to have details for you when we come right back after this. You see the lineup of people there, we'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The hostage situation at the James T. Vaughn Correctional Center in Delaware ended tragically. Lauren Simonetti with details right now.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Hey, Maria. So state police rushed into the building when the two hostages were still being held from last night into early this morning. One of them, a prison officer was found dead, they were taken hostage by the inmates. The other one fortunately was rescued. The correctional officers union president said, "It is a sad day for Delaware Correctional Officers," well, a sad day indeed. Inmates had told a local newspaper that concerns about their treatment and the leadership of the U.S. prompted their actions.

All right. Let's move to markets here. Big day for earnings, Merck's report just coming in. Quarterly profit in line with estimates. The company posted and adjusted profit of 89 cents a share, revenue however narrowly missed the estimate, hurt by weak sales of its key Immuno-oncology drug KEYTRUDA as well as its diabetes medicine. And it was a record Christmas for Ecommerce sales, that is expected to boost Amazon earnings when the company reports after the closing bell today, Amazon did say that this holiday season, it was its best one ever.

ChipotleMexican Grill also reports after the close, the company still working to recover from those big losses from foodborne bacteria that actually made some customers sick. That was back in 2015. Chipotle has already said that sales for the holiday quarter probably fell five percent. And visa reporting after the close today as well, analysts expected the company to post a profit 78 cents a share. Well, it's February 2nd, groundhog day and Punxsutawney Phil says, "I'm sorry, six more weeks of winter."

A short time ago he happened to see his shadow and according to legend that means spring's arrival is going to have wait a little bit longer, how accurate is Phil? Well, according to reports, going back to 1988, he's been correct 46 percent at the time. And finally, First Lady Melania Trump will be moving to White House at the start of summer. Aides say she will be settling in at the end of the school year and splitting her time between New York and D.C. The White House also announced Lindsey Reynolds will be joining the first lady's team as chief of staff, apart from that job, Reynolds is also an assistant to President Donald Trump. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Lauren. Coming up, Tex Tillerson taking the helm as secretary of state despite delays caused by democrats. The future of the party next when we take a look at confirmation process, where do we stand? Then Tasca losing a part of its title as it looks to expand beyond cars, the changes to the automaker coming up. Back in a moment. .

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. happy Thursday everybody. Thanks you so much for joining us this morning. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, February 2nd. Your top stories 8:30 a.m. on the east coast right now. We are awaiting comments from President Trump this morning in Washington. He is set to speak at National Prayer Breakfast momentarily. We will take you there live as soon as he takes to the podium President Trump's cabinet finally gains another member, Rex Tillerson, sworn in, as the next secretary of state after he was approved by the senate yesterday, in a 56- 43 vote. Tillerson just latest confirmation fight between the president and democrats.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: -- very demeaning on other side. And they want to make you look as bad as possible, I think there is a certain dishonesty if they go against -- from not very long ago and he did get a unanimous endorsement.

REX TILLERSON, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF STATE: I'm not concerned about that and I can tell you why, because I think that their record of obstruction is going to wear same with the people. We didn't obstruct and so we think that our -- republican president ought to have the same consideration.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK MORNINGS WITH MARIA HOST: The very latest on the tensions coming up this morning. President Trump escalating his fight with Mexico. The Commander-in-Chief telling the country to take care of bad hombres. This says Secretary of Homeland Security John Kelly says the wall could be finished in just two years.

Macy's is known for its sale but the company could be up for sale. Why the outgoing CEO Terry Lundgren is reportedly considering selling the company. The stock this morning, looking up on these rumors.

Earnings. The story once again on Wall Street. Amazon, a name to watch certainly after the close tonight. Company will report its fourth quarter. Analysts are expecting a big quarter given it is right in the middle of the holiday shopping season for Amazon. We'll get those numbers for you as soon as they hit the tape after the close tonight.

Broader market this morning. Looking lower, take a look. We're expecting an opening of about 50 points low on the DOW Industrials. The Nasdaq, S&P 500 also in the red this morning.

One Commander-in-Chief ready to do the Super Bowl shuffle. The details behind President George H.W. Bush's coin flip this Sunday.

And the big game. Maybe just a few days away but the party is already in full swing we are taking a live to Houston, where everybody from NFL Stars to astronauts are getting in on the fun.

First on Capitol Hill now. President Trump sending a strong message to Senate Democrats who intend to block confirmations. Justice's Cabinet finally gains another member. Blake Burman with the very latest right now at the White House, Blake.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: Hi there, Maria. Good morning to you. Despite reservations really on both sides of the aisle with past business dealings with Russia, the Senate yesterday did indeed confirmed Rex Tillerson to become the next Secretary of State. A very narrow nomination but it passed, nonetheless.

He then came here to the White House, the Former ExxonMobil CEO did and with the President and Vice President by his side, he was officially sworn in. The president also turned some heads yesterday at the White House earlier in the day in which he appeared to give the OK for the Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to change the Senate rules, should it get to that point with another nomination. That being the Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch.

(BEHIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If we end up with the same gridlock that they've had in Washington for the last -- longer than eight years in all fairness to President Obama -- a lot longer than eight years. Then we end up with that gridlock, I would say if you can Mitch, don't go near. Because that would be an absolute shame if a man of this quality was caught up in the web.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: You heard the president there say go nuclear. That refers to the so-called Nuclear Option, which would eliminate the 60 votes filibuster threshold that Democrats are calling for and bring it down to 51. I asked the White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer about this yesterday Maria, whether the White House would be comfortable going forward with that path, Spicer told me that it's not the president's preference at this point, and that essentially, it would Mitch McConnell's call. We'll see if it gets to that point, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Blake. Thank you so much. Blake Burman at the White House. Joining us right now is the man who ran against Nancy Pelosi for Minority Leader. OhioCongressman Tim Ryan is with us. And congressman, it's good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

TIM RYAN, UNITED STATES CONGRESSMAN OF OHIO: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: So, your reaction to all of these stall tactics on the side of Democrats, Sir, I mean, obviously, they are stopping and trying to do whatever they can to stall President Trump from having his cabinet in place.

RYAN: Well, I mean, that's the process. I mean, we're not messy democracy, that's where we live. You know, you saw it happen during President Obama's tenure where the Republicans were literally blocking every single thing he tried to do. Jobs, bill of Supreme Court Nominee, so now there is some real disagreement I think, whether it's with the Supreme Court Justice or some of his nominees that violates some of the basic values that, I think, Democrats have.

So, it's important for us to stand up, Republicans have the majority, they are getting some of their nominees through, but this is all part of the process, and I don't think it's anything unnecessary is happening but we get - we have to stand up for what we believe in too.

BARTIROMO: What specific values are being violated?

RYAN: Well, I think if you look at The Supreme Court Nominee, Trump, you know, campaigned about draining the swamp. The Supreme Court Nominee is not for any kind of campaign finance reform at all. I think if you look, you know, at DeVos for example, the Secretary of Education absolutely no experience in public education and also owes Ohio $5 million from fines that she got a few years ago, when she was involved in another organization that she hasn't paid. I mean, these are legitimate things that -

BARTIROMO: Well wait a second -

RYAN: Obviously, we need to talk about.

BARTIROMO: When you say Judge Gorsuch, I mean, this is the individual who was confirmed unanimously just 10 years ago by Republicans and Democrats. So, what changed other than him being Donald Trump's pick?

RYAN: Well, I think the fact that Donald Trump campaigned on draining the swamp, that he is not for draining the swamp, he is for, you know, unfettered money coming into politics with many, many people are against. President Trump campaigned --

Maria: Yes. I want to ask you about draining the swamp.

RYAN: Hold on. Hold on, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Go ahead.

RYAN: He also campaigned on helping working class people where the Supreme Court Nominee is against right to work which would allow working class people to organize. So, I think these are legitimate things that we are going to have fights over. Let's not make too big a of a deal out of it.

BARTIROMO: OK, all right. Well, the problem is that the president needs a team in place in order to execute some of the promises he's made. I got to get my team in here for you but I have one more question on draining the swamp for you because there's an article right now, saying Nancy Pelosi is leading her party into oblivion. I mean, Nancy Pelosi said that the -- Judge Gorsuch is hostile to women's productive rights, hostility toward children and school, children with autism, hostile appointments. And as far as President Trump, she says he's been wreck less and incompetent in his recent Executive Order. I mean, does she not understand what just happened in terms of the election? She is going against what the people just voted for.

RYAN: Well, I mean Democrats, not to be too frank, but we are in oblivion as we speak now. I mean, we are completely wiped out in the election so we're trying to work our way back. But I think Donald Trump also campaigned, Maria, on stability and he's doing everything in his power to make the globe more unstable at this point.

You see, the rally with the stock market has subsided a bit because he is picking fights, he's doing things with -- the Muslim ban and immigration that makes us look hostile to our allies in Muslim countries and Muslims here in the United States when we know that these are very important things that the kind of stability that we need.

He campaigned on bringing us that stability. And he is making things unstable, he campaigned on making us stronger and the Muslim ban makes it harder for us to prosecute the war on terrorism.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Congressman, I have to push back. It's not a Muslim ban. These are seven countries that were identified by the Obama Administration. And the restrictions are based on country, not religion, first and foremost. But I want to get back to Nancy Pelosi and the loss of the Democrats in rebuilding the party and making a comeback is -- but is the way to do that, this kind of fierce rhetoric and opposition that you're getting from not only Nancy Pelosi, but also Chuck Schumer. Is that how you win over voters over the next two to four years?

RYAN: Well, you know, you have to take a stand on things that you believe in, and it may not always be popular in the moment. I'm not into real hostile rhetoric. I'm not into inflaming the situation. We have enough of that in Washington. We need to reach out to each other and see if we can find some common ground. But

I will tell you, that it is the Chief Executive's responsibility to do that. I mean, he hasn't even reached out to his own national security people, for example, with the immigration issue that we were just talking about. He even didn't talk to his own people. They're not talking to Democrats, that's the responsibility of the President of The United States. President Obama did a lot of reaching out to Republicans, early on, through a lot of the affordable care stuff. He was always reaching out.

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on. The Affordable Care Act? Don't go there. He don't care and he pushed through and he had absolutely no support on the Republican side at all.

RYAN: Are you kidding me? He had no support? I'm saying he reached out for months and months. And including in the Stimulus Bill, incorporated the tax cuts into the Stimulus Bill that many Democrats didn't want. We wanted straight infrastructure spending to juice up the economy.

BARTIROMO: Why did he have to do so many Executive Orders, then? Then how come he had to do so many Executive Orders?

RYAN: OK. Because the Republicans were blocking every single thing he did. He had no choice. But if he wants to get anything done to do Executive Orders, you know it and I know it -

BARTIROMO: No. I don't know that. I don't know that at all.

RYAN: Mitch McConnell said that his number one goal -- Mitch McConnell said his number one goal was to make sure President Obama didn't have a second term.

BARTIROMO: Well, I think -

RYAN: They blocked his jobs bill, they didn't vote, not one vote for health care, their whole M.O. was to destroy Obama and make him a one termer. So, don't turn around two weeks into Trump's presidency and say, "Boy, you guys are being really unfair." Look, this is not the rotary club. This is politics. It's a full contact support. If you can't take the heat, get out of the kitchen.

BARTIROMO: Ryan, I think it's also important to know that part of the reason Donald Trump won the election is because of those Executive Orders. It was as much a repudiation against President Obama, as it was the fact that there was no message from your candidate.

RYAN: Well, look.

BARTIROMO: Let's not forget what the reality is. Your team lost.

RYAN: And I like some of his Executive Orders. Small business regulations, I agree with it. Re-negotiating TPP, I agree with it. Finding a way to make NAFTA work for places like Youngstown in Warren Akron, Ohio sit? Let's sit down and do that. I'm not here to butt heads with him at every turn. I'm here to work with him if we can. But as I said, he's not even reaching out to his own people on policy decisions, he's certainly not reaching out the Democrats. But when we stand ready if there is something we can work on.

MCDOWELL: Congressman, one final question. Are the Democrats going to put anybody under 70 years old in power? In leadership?

RYAN: Well -- I did my part I did my part to try to try. You know, I think we do need new faces in the democratic party and I think we need a solid approach that reaches out to all corners of the country. I think we have a good agenda that we need to just push and get out. We need to rebuild the country, we need broadband in every corner of the country to unlock certain communities that just can't compete in the new economy because they don't have the new America 2.0 infrastructure like broadband. And, you know, education reform and all the rest. So we have an agenda but we've got to be willing to sit down and try to get it through.

BARTIROMO: Well, part of that issue is the party is being hijacked by the extreme left. Is that a fair statement?

RYAN: Well, we're in an era in the country of extreme partisanship and I think President Trump needs to do a better job of figuring out how to do things without inciting everybody in the country and in the world. Now you look at what is going on with refugees and people coming over here.

Look, no bureaucratic system is perfect. If there's things we need to do to sit down and some, fine. But the reality is, if we're going to be real concerned with refugees coming over here or people coming over here as terrorists, they're probability not going to come from Yemen. They're probably not going to come from Syria. >

BARTIROMO: Why not?

RYAN: They're probably going to be smart enough to come through a European country into the United States. And so let's sit down and figure out how we can work with our European allies to tighten things up to make sure that we are covering the entire ground. We have a really strong vetting process, of course it can be improved but he didn't need to do it in a way that makes it hostile to where tech companies are freaking out because, you know, they have Muslim workers to where a doctor at the Cleveland clinic is getting stopped and not allowed back into the country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RYAN: You don't need to do this. It just - there's too much chaos with Trump, too much drama. Sit down, relax, breathe in through nose and let's figure out how to work together and get the country going again.

BARTIROMO: Real quick. Peter Kiernan.

PETER KIERNAN, NEW YORK TIMES BEST-SELLING AUTHOR: Well I have to say I watched you closely when you were running your campaign for -- excuse me -- minority leader. I think you would have made a great one. I don't believe you would have fought at every single step, at every single turn, the way Schumer and Nancy Pelosi are. Do you have a reaction to that?

RYAN: I think we do need to pick our spots. I think we've got to find points of agreement and -- but there are people are -- excited about a couple of these nominees. I think that the immigration issue, the Muslim issue, insight a lot of people's sensibilities including mine that, you know, you're going to put Muslims back in the line trying to get in the country. You're going to tell refugees who want to come into a safe haven, sometimes United States, sometimes other countries that are coming from a war that we started guys. I mean, we started this war. So we have some responsibility. So, no. I don't think you fight on every turn, I think you try to find some common ground.

But when there are basic issues that violate our values, you stand up and you fight. And we're giving him, I think, will give him a lot more hearings for Supreme Court justice than the Republicans gave the President Obama. So, it's important for us to remember that as well.

BARTIROMO: Congressman, it's good to have you on the program this morning. We'll be watching. Thanks so much.

RYAN: Thanks, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Congressman Tim Ryan, joining us there. Coming up, we are waiting remarks from President Trump at the National Breakfast. The Prayer Breakfast. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. 45 minutes away from the opening bell. Markets are looking lower this morning. We are at the lows of the morning right now. And the DOW Industrials average now expecting a decline of about 60 points. NASDAQ, down in 11. Couple of names are watching Macy's. The stock is looking higher this morning reportedly considering a possible sale. The New York Post is reporting that longtime CEO Terry Lundgren is set to be weighing the move before he steps down later this quarter. Macy's shares and we're seeing a bit off. Tesla Motors dropping the motors. The name change to Tesla Inc. chose the company's ambition to move beyond just selling high end electric cars and shifting into energy products like solar panels and home batteries. Tesla agreed to acquire Solar City, remember, for $2.6 billion. That was back in November.

Blowout earnings from big technology names like Microsoft, Apple, Facebook. Amazon is reporting tonight. And the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY", Stuart Varney joins me. Taking a look at tech in the spotlight, Stu. Good morning.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK VARNEY & COMPANY HOST: I continue my astonishment at the financial performance of America's big tech companies. As you point out, Apple, $246 billion in cash, Facebook last night, 1.8 billion monthly users and a ton of money coming over every year. And tonight, it's Amazon. I don't know whether they're going to disappoint or what. But I do know that if you look at the numbers, it will be a shock.

Maria, you and I have covered financial news for a few years. I have covered it for decades longer than you have and I have never, ever seen such a concentration of financial power among the four or five top American big name technology companies. Never seen this before. And remember, they are now in opposition to President Trump. Both on ideologic grounds and on trade grounds, on visa grounds, this is quite a confrontation that's coming here.

BARTIROMO: It's incredible. Part of the issue, I think, is because technology is seeped into so many other industries, Stu. Right? I mean, tech has changed transportation, it's changed health care, it's changed retailing. So, one of the reasons for power base is that it's not just traditional tech, it's technology changing so many other industries.

VARNEY: That is very true. I mean, it seeped into the automobile industry.

BARTIROMO: That, too.

VARNEY: I mean, I don't know what percentage of a car these days comes from Silicon Valley or is computer oriented. It's big and it's growing. I just -- I don't think I've ever seen that kind of concentration of financial power. The money these guys have, the influence that brings, is really astonishing. I love it, by the way.

BARTIROMO: We know President Trump doesn't like monopolies. So, we'll see where that goes.

VARNEY: Who wants a monopoly?

BARTIROMO: See you in about 10 minutes, Stu.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. "VARNEY & COMPANY" again at the top of the hour right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart, 9:00 a.m. Eastern this morning.

Coming up, the NFL takes its Super Bowl patrons on the ride of their life. Our own Cheryl Casone is on the ground in Houston with former NFL Star, Jack Brewer. Check it out. We're going to join them momentarily. back in a minute.

Then, they took an interstellar journey that made even jack brewer scream.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Houston, of course home to NASA's Johnson Space Center so it should come as no surprise that the space travel agency will play a part in the pre-Super Bowl festivities. Our own Cheryl Casone and Former NFL Star Jack Brewer took a ride on NASA's 90-foot virtual reality simulated trip to mars and back. And they lived to tell the tale. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK FINANCIAL CONTRIBUTOR: Maria, good morning. Yes, it was a two-minute ride but it was full of thrills. NASA does, someday, want go to mars. They're working with Boeing and race it on to make it happen. But as far as the ride itself, Jack, how would you describe what we went through yesterday for Maria?

JACK BREWER, FORMER NFL STAR: I was freaked out.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BREWER: Whoa.

CASONE: We're ready. Let's do this.

BREWER: Let's do this.

CASONE: We're about to go up 90 feet so we can drop 90 feet. Jack, you are afraid of heights. Right?

BREWER: I can't believe you talked me into this.

CASONE: We're standing in the middle of the field in NRG Stadium.

BREWER: Maria, the only thing missing here is you.

CASONE: Oh, boy. We're above the Earth.

BREWER: Oh, my God.

CASONE: We're in space, Jack. We're on the Orion Spacecraft.

BREWER: Yes.

CASONE: We're approaching Mars.

BREWER: It's kind of beautiful, actually.

CASONE: Yes.

BREWER: Wow.

BREWER: I did not say anything that was not on T.V. It was amazing.

CASONE: That was cool. That was cool. Jack, here we go.

BREWER: Oh, man.

CASONE: That was crazy. Are you OK?

BREWER: Yes. I was just happy that I -

CASONE: I'm a little dizzy. Look, we just want to mars, Maria. you owe us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: What we do for you, Maria. Right, Jack?

BREWER: That is right. We love you.

CASONE: We love you. It was a lot of fun. It was a bit crazy out there but all the fans can come in and experience that today. If they're in Texas, come on down in the Super Bowl live.

BARTIROMO: You guys have real spunk. Dagen and I were just talking about when you went on that roller-coaster ride, Cheryl. Wow.

Meanwhile, how about this, guys? Former President George H.W. Bush and his wife Barbara are flipping the coin before the 2017 Super Bowl according to their spokesperson. Jack, what do you think about that? Who do you think the former president is rooting for?

BREWER: Well, I mean. I am sure he's already a fan. But down deeply in his heart, he wishes he was watching the Dallas Cowboys. But you know, President Bush is a very, very admired person in Texas, you know. I am a Texan as well as Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes. This is our home state, Maria. But you know, the thing is, this is his hometown and there's so much buzz because there's just so many well wishes from him that are coming from all over just on a local perspective. But I can't imagine what that stadium is going to be like when he comes out to do that coin toss on Sunday. We are going to be there so we will let you know.

BREWER: No question.

BARTIROMO: All right, guys. Thank you, Cheryl and jack. We will see you later, thanks for that. And remember you can watch Super Bowl only on one network live on the Fox Network. This Sunday night, 6:30 pm Eastern. We will be watching.

CASONE: Yes, we will.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a short break. Final thoughts from our all-star panel when we come right back. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: We're awaiting comments from President Trump at the National Prayer Breakfast. We want to get some final thoughts are we're all scratching our heads trying to figure out what Congressman Tim Ryan just said about we started this war. Twitter's going nuts about it too. Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I just -- to push back on that, I don't know exactly what he's talking about as if we asked for 9/11 going down that road, but in terms of Syria and the refugee crisis, Trump -- President Trump is now trying to deal with. The situation in Syria erupted because of the vacuum by President Obama. There was a red line that wasn't honored. And Assad and Putin, essentially took over. So, let's blame and put blame where it needs to lie.

BARTIROMO: And that's the bottom line. Thank you Morgan Ortagus, Peter Kiernan, Dagen McDowell. It's a pleasure. We'll see you tomorrow, everybody. Here's Stuart.

urn:contentItem:5T0S-B821-DYR7-C194-00000-00Buoyant Economy or a Blip? 4 Tips for Investing Before the Party Ends;Wealth Matters2018-08-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:30:42ZLexisNexisYOUR-MONEYBuoyant Economy or a Blip? 4 Tips for Investing Before the Party EndsWealth MattersPAUL SULLIVANABSTRACT

The economy has been growing since March 2009, but some are skeptical that the expansion will continue. Experts offer advice for investing wisely in times of doubt.

FULL TEXT

When it comes to how the latest economic data could have an impact on investors, two opposite interpretations emerge.

Growth of 4.1 percent in the second quarter is a sign of a buoyant economy set to keep growing for years to come, continuing a nearly decade-long expansion since the financial crisis in 2008.

Or growth of 4.1 percent in the second quarter is a short-term blip brought about by tax cuts that gave people a little extra money in their paycheck but is unsustainable in the face of mounting federal debt, higher tariffs and the prospect of a trade war that could hurt large portions of the United States economy.

On Friday, the Labor Department released the jobs report for July, showing the economy added 157,000 jobs, fewer than the expected gain of 190,000. The jobless rate dropped to 3.9 percent, suggesting slack in the labor market, but wages are growing slowly.

Your takeaway depends on your overall view of the country and the economy.

"In 23 years of doing this, I cannot really remember a time when a statistic comes out and you hear such diametrically opposed interpretations of it," said Andrew Crowell, vice chairman of wealth management at D. A. Davidson & Company, which manages $48.2 billion. "There is no gray zone. It's only black and white, which makes it an interesting time to be an investor."

Who's correct on the data will not be known until the economic impact is felt, which could take months or even years. But for investors, any plan based on waiting or wishing is not ideal.

After all, even before President Trump began to shake up economic norms, with his criticism of the Federal Reserve, threats of tariffs and nonchalance about government debt, investors were skeptical of the economic expansion, which has run, with a few minor dips, from March 2009 to the present.

A wait-and-see approach on investing can be costly, but moving too quickly at this stage could be ruinous if the market goes into a correction. Advisers to some of the country's wealthiest people say to keep investing but to do it wisely.

Here are four tips for investors in a time of caution:

Diversify Your Portfolio

Mr. Trump has made many comments that in a different time would have caused the economy to tank. Military threats against North Korea and Iran, tariffs against the United States' largest trading partners, all manner of statements about Russia - none of them has caused a market correction.

Instead, the opposite has happened this year, as investors find opportunities in market fluctuations. "We've seen cash come in to buy on the dips," Mr. Crowell said.

And for a seemingly sound reason: Companies continue to grow. The Republican tax cut that was enacted last year and a rollback of financial regulations have helped, but so have strong earnings that have outpaced price increases.

"The stimulative measures have bolstered confidence that growth and the economy is going to be strong over the next couple of years," Mr. Crowell said.

Advisers agree that the recovery has been running for some time and is near the point where bull markets typically begin to falter. But that does not mean the run will end this year or next or even the year after that.

"Consumer wealth is at all-time highs when you factor in home prices and the stock market," said Henry B. Smith, co-chief investment officer at the Haverford Trust Company, which manages $8 billion. "One of the lacking ingredients throughout this has been business investment, and that is starting to pick up."

Mr. Smith is advising his clients to have the maximum exposure to equities that they can stomach. But he is also telling them to think more broadly about equities.

Investors often overlook the moderating role of value stocks, which are steady, dividend-paying stocks that can help weather various economic storms. Instead, they often pursue the higher returns of growth stocks, which are expected to grow at an above-average rate.

Mr. Smith said investors should think about trimming back investments in manufacturing, technology and financial services to increase holdings of consumer staples, health care, telecommunication and utility stocks, the basics of value investing.

He cited last week's sudden drop in the value of Facebook as reason to broaden your view of equities. "Last week was a good reminder that stocks that go up sharply can also come down sharply," he said.

Be Aware of Opportunities

Many investors seem willing to forget that the returns of the past decade have been strong and that replicating them going forward may be difficult. In other words, stay invested in riskier assets while they continue to run, because selling them too early could hurt your portfolio.

"When we look at demographics and economic projections, there isn't going to be as much population growth and consumption," said Anthony Roth, chief investment officer at Wilmington Trust. "Most of the world has a population moving to slower consumption as they age. While this economic cycle is continuing, the risk of missing out is even greater."

Mr. Roth pointed to the reaction over the flattening of the yield curve, which tracks the difference between the interest rate on short-term bonds and long-term bonds. He said talk about the yield curve inverting - which means long-term borrowing costs become less than those in the short term - was premature.

"The strongest period of the market cycle is from the time of yield curve inversion to the peak of the equity market, which is usually nine to 12 months after that," Mr. Roth said. "We haven't even gotten to the inversion yet, which would suggest there's significant opportunity right now."

Yet investors need to pay attention. "The alarm is when the yield curve inverts," he said. "It's a predictor of both recessions and returns in the market."

Actively monitoring economic data and what it presages is a smart strategy.

Pick Recession-Resistant Stocks

Most analysts believe that Mr. Trump is bluffing on tariffs and that they are being used as a negotiating tool. This comes from the school of thought that favors what the president does over what he says.

For instance, after saying so many harsh things about European trading partners, Mr. Trump embraced Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the European Commission, just last week.

"The worst case is, Trump just gets in a fight with China, Europe and everyone else and we see an escalation of tariffs that slows world trade and has a significant impact on the U.S. economic cycle, increases inflationary pressures and ultimately reduces output," said John S. Osterweis, chairman and chief investment officer of Osterweis Capital Management, which manages about $7 billion.

That would be crushing, but it is not the only possible outcome.

"The flip side is, Trump really is a master negotiator and what he's doing is trying to move away from multilateral trade agreements to bilateral agreements," Mr. Osterweis said. That may produce better trade deals, he said.

Lacking any idea as to which outcome to expect, Mr. Osterweis has been encouraging clients to invest in companies whose outlooks are less dependent on the economy or a particular industry, he said.

"You could think of a Google, where people's search habits aren't going to change dramatically if there's a recession and there's already an inexorable migration of ad dollars to that company," he said. "You could look at a drug company with a blockbuster drug coming through the pipeline or a Disney, where they have the next unbelievably popular movie coming out."

The opposite would be manufacturing companies like automakers that stockpile inventory and could struggle to sell it in a recession. Still, some combination of different types of companies is the more prudent bet.

Consider the Tax Implications

Facebook's loss of nearly 20 percent of its value in one day was substantial. But Mr. Crowell said it should not cause people to run from the Big Tech stocks like Alphabet, Amazon, Facebook and Netflix.

What it should do is get people thinking about the need to examine their portfolios. "It's prudent to be mindful that those four names don't define a diversified portfolio," he said.

Another reason not to sell off stocks that have appreciated greatly is taxes. People who have held those stocks for a long time have watched them run up in value, which means they are going to owe a lot of money in taxes when they sell them.

Todd Morgan, chairman of Bel Air Investment Advisors, which manages about $8 billion for high-net-worth families, said he shows clients how much the stock of a fundamentally strong company would have to fall before selling it made sense.

"People don't look at the after-tax returns," Mr. Morgan said. "I've had several calls about tech stocks the past few days, all asking, 'Should we stay in or get out?'"

If an investor thinks a company is going to drop below what would be owed in capital gains taxes, then it is time to get out.

Investors need to keep paying attention to company fundamentals and economic indicators focused on inflation and wages. If either of those runs too high, the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates, which could bring the equity party to an end.

Since neither is happening now, the best advice is to stay invested and stay alert.
